vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/a79b74cd-ce2a-435a-9250-ad5453874690">ZIMBABWE</keyword>         <topcClas>Economic conditions and indicators - Economics</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>Published monthly since 1948, the <i>International Financial Statistics (IFS)</i> database is the principal statistical publication of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and is the standard source for all aspects of international and domestic finance. The database contains approximately 32,000 time series for over 200 countries and geographical areas. It reports, for most countries, time series data on exchange rates, balance of payments, international liquidity, money and banking, interest rates, prices, production, international transactions, government accounts, national accounts and population.<br> <br> Selected data, including data on Fund accounts, international reserves and international trade, are also aggregated into regional and world tables.<br> <br> Data are reported in a mixture of indexes, national currencies, US Dollars and SDRs (the basket currency the IMF uses as a unit of account). Most annual data begin in 1948; quarterly and monthly data generally begin in 1957; most balance of payments data begin in 1970.<br> <br> This database was first provided by the UK Data Service in December 2003. The UK Data Service web site includes further information on its <i>IMF IFS</i> holdings, including a <a href=" http://ukdataservice.ac.uk//use-data/guides/dataset/ifs.aspx" title=" IMF International Financial Statistics dataset user guide">dataset user guide</a> and details of <a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.5257/imf/ifs/2011-09" title=" IMF International Financial Statistics latest database updates">latest database updates</a>.<br> <br> <b>Citation:</b> The bibliographic citation for the database is: International Monetary Fund (<i>{YYYY}</i>): International Financial Statistics (<i>{date/edition of dataset}</i>). Mimas, University of Manchester. DOI: <i>{edition specific doi - e.g. <a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.5257/imf/ifs/2011-09">http://dx.doi.org/10.5257/imf/ifs/2011-09</a>}</i>. <br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>Topics covered include:<ul><li>budget deficits</li><li>budgets</li><li>capital</li><li>capital budgets</li><li>currencies</li><li>debts, external</li><li>debts, public</li><li>econometrics</li><li>economic analysis</li><li>economic conditions</li><li>economic forecasting</li><li>economic growth</li><li>economic policy</li><li>economic structure</li><li>exchange rates</li><li>export credit</li><li>finance, public</li><li>financial policy</li><li>financial resources</li><li>financial statistics</li><li>fiscal policy</li><li>foreign exchange</li><li>foreign exchange rates</li><li>gross National Product</li><li>international finance</li><li>international liquidity</li><li>investments, foreign</li><li>macroeconomics</li><li>monetary policy</li><li>money</li><li>money supply</li><li>national accounting</li><li>national income/accounting</li><li>state aid</li></ul></abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd>Most annual data begin in 1948; quarterly and monthly data generally begin in 1957; most balance of payments data begin in 1970.</timePrd> <timeMeth>Time Series</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>monthly, quarterly and annual. These data are updated once a month.</timeMeth>         <sampProc>See documentation for details.</sampProc>         <collMode>The IFS data are drawn from a huge variety of sources including government departments, national accounts, central banks, the United Nations (UN), Eurostat, the International Labour Organization and private financial institutions. There are further details about the document 'An Introduction to IFS' in the <a href=" http://ukdataservice.ac.uk//use-data/guides/dataset/ifs.aspx" title=" IMF International Financial Statistics dataset user guide"> dataset user guide</a> which provides information on methodologies.</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting used. As a result of this policy the IMF datasets hosted by the UK Data Service are now freely available to all.
